title.narrative: COVID-19 BLIAP - Being LGBTI in Asia and Pacific, Phase 3, 2020-2021
COVID-19 BLIAP- Att vara HBTQI-person i Asien och Oceanien, Fas 3, 2020-2021

description.narrative: New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Being LGBTI in Asia and Pacific (BLIAP) is a regional project implemented by UNDP. It has previously been given funding from Sida between 2014-2018. In 2019 the BLIAP entered into a phase 3 with implementation period 2019-2023 and continued to receive Swedish funds for 2019 activities. The Being LGBTI in the Asia Pacific (BLIAP) Phase 3 programme builds upon previous work in Phase 1 and 2. BLIAP Phase 3 (2019-2023) will implement a five-year plan strategically focusing on five development dimensions, set out below. These areas of work build on the recommendations of the Being LGBTI in Asia Regional Dialogue in 2015 and the achievements of BLIA Phase 2. They also reflect the key areas of inclusion identified through a global consultative process with civil society and stakeholders on the LGBTI inclusion index in 2016. The COVID-19 has created a perfect storm of crises across the region, not just in regards to health: COVID-19 creates a socio-economic crise, disproportionately impacting already marginalized persons within societies and causing significant human rights challenges. The pandemic is disrupting the capacity of LGBTI organisations to respond to challenges, and new ways of working need to be developed. According to UNDP, the crisis also presents an opportunity for transformative change and a possibility to build back more inclusively and sustainabily. Sidas assessment is that a cost extension will allow for UNDP to continue to adapt to changing circumstances and support the LGBTI community in times of crises. It is positive that UNDP works with an expanded approach that focuses on adequate representation by young LGBTI-persons and emerging issues such as LGBTI inclusion in climate action and adaptation. This also strengthens the relevance in relation to the on-going Strategy for Regional Asia and the Pacific (2016-2021).

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Being LGBTI in Asia and Pacific (BLIAP) är ett regionalt projekt som genomförs av UNDP. Det har tidigare beviljats medel från Sida mellan 2014–2018. År 2019 gick BLIAP in i fas 3 med genomförandeperioden 2019-2023. Fas 3 av Being LGBTI in the Asia Pacific (BLIAP) bygger på tidigare arbete och resultat i fas 1 och 2 och genomförs med fokus på fem strategiska dimensioner. Dessa arbetsområden bygger på rekommendationer från Being LGBTI in Asia Regional Dialogue under 2015 och resultaten från fas 2. De återspeglar också de områden som identifierades som viktigast att inkludera under en global konsultationsprocess med civila samhället och aktörer kring LGBTI inclusion index 2016. UNDP och Sida har haft en nära dialog kring hur COVID-19 och politisk turbulens har påverkat programmet och dess målgrupp. Att vara HBTQI i Asien och Oceanien ökar risken för marginalisering och social exkludering. COVID-19 skapar inte bara en hälsokris, utan även en socio-ekonomisk kris där redan marginaliserade grupper drabbas extra hårt. Samtidigt skapar krisen också en möjlighet att bygga tillbaka bättre på ett sätt som är mer hållbart och inkluderande, och det finns ett momentum att bygga vidare på. Genom en avtalsändring fortsätter ambassaden att stödja UNDP under 2021 som är det sista året för den regionala strategin för Asien och Oceanien. Ambassadens bedömning är att denna avtalsändring möjliggör för UNDP att fortsätta stödja den regionala HBTQI-communityn under en tid av kris. UNDP har arbetat aktivt för att anpassa stödet till den nya situationen och stöd för ökad digital säkerhet kommer också att ingå i budgeten. Strategirelevansen bedöms ha ökat genom att UNDP arbetar mer integrerat med miljö och klimat, genom att verka för ökad representation av HBTQI-personer inom klimatområdet.

Being LGBTI in Asia and Pacific (BLIAP) is a regional project implemented by UNDP. It has previously been given funding from Sida between 2014-2018, first under the Swedish Government's Regional Strategy for Development Cooperation for SouthEast Asia, and then under the the Swedish Government's Regional Strategy for Development Cooopeation for Asia and the Pacific. In 2019 the BLIAP entered into a phase 3 with implementation period 2019-2023 and continued to receive Swedish funds for 2019 activities, but from the Global Strategy for Sweden’s development cooperation in the areas of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. Funds of 5 msek were chanelled through the Global LGBTI partnership with USAID. In total, the Project has received 37 202 000 SEK from Sweden during 2014-2019. The Being LGBTI in the Asia Pacific (BLIAP) Phase 3 programme builds upon previous work in Phase 1 and 2. Phase 1, initiated in 2012, focused on developing an evidence base of the lived experience of LGBTI people through research and the engagement of civil society Groups throughout the region. BLIAP Phase 3 (2019-2023) will implement a five year plan strategically focusing on five development dimensions, set out below. 1: Legal reform and political and civic participation – The project will promote development of an enabling environment for the development and implementation of protective laws and policies that are inclusive of LGBTI people, including antidiscrimination legislation, decriminalization of homosexuality, and legal gender recognition for transgender people. 2: Access to justice, personal security and anti-violence protection – The project will promote fair and equal treatment of LGBTI persons by the justice and law enforcement systems, including improved access to justice and enhanced personalsecurity and antiviolence protection. This will include addressing hate crimes, police abuses, domestic violence and other forms of violence. 3: Health – The project will promote improved access to health and HIV services and address health disparities, including inequitable access to services, pathologization of homosexuality and transgender people, and respect for the bodily integrity of intersex people. This will include the development of policies and guidelines for health care services that are sensitive to and respectful of the health rights of LGBTI people. 4: Economic well-being – The project will promote inclusive, non-discriminatory hiring practices and equitable work environments for LGBTI people to address access to and rights violations in employment. The scope of work will extend to linkages with livelihoods and poverty alleviation programmes, particularly for the most marginalized groups within the LGBTI spectrum. 5: Education – The project will promote LGBTI people’s equitable access to an education system that is inclusive, non-discriminatory, and appropriate to the needs of the 21st century. This will include addressing harassment and bullying, inclusive curricula, and freedom of gender expression in education institutions. Efforts will include ensuring LGBTI population have access to training and education which is seeks to build 21st century skills and capacity for utilizing new technologies. The goal of the project is to promote LGBTI inclusion in Asia Pacific across five development dimensions: political and civic participation, access to justice and personal safety, economic well-being, health and education. The end-of-project outcome is: LGBTI social and economic inclusion in Asia Pacific advanced through promulgation and implementation of protective laws, policies and programmes which mitigate discrimination and violence, ensure access to LGBTI appropriate services.Three lower level or interim outcomes will contribute towards achieving the overall end of project outcome. They are: 1. Improved capacity and commitment of governments and NHRIs to develop, implement and monitor LGBTI inclusive and protective laws, policies and programmes and to ensure equitable access to services that meet the needs of LGBTI people.2. Improved capacity and increased participation of LGBTI community groups in dialogue and advocacy with stakeholders – including governments, civil society, NHRIs, the private sector and youth development partners – on the development, implementation and monitoring of LGBTI inclusive and protective laws, policies and practices as well as the promotion of equitable access to opportunities and services that meet the needs of LGBTI people.3. Improved capacity and commitment of the business sector, other private sector actors, and social protection initiatives to develop, implement and monitor LGBTI inclusive policies and programmes supporting access to employment, livelihoods, innovative social entrepreneurship and poverty alleviation. The end-of-project outcome for the previous phase of the project focused on increased capacity and willingness of rights holders and duty bearers to advocate for, develop and implement LGBTI inclusive public lawa, policies and programmes. While BLIAP´s design recoginizes the need to further develop the capacity of rights holders and duty bearers, including affording a higher priority to developing private sector partner capacity committment, this is framed within the context of a more ambitious end-of-project outcome which buold on existing foundations laid by the project to achieve an incresed number of protective laws, policies and programmes which advance LGBTI inclusion.

tag.narrative: 10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors, oavsett ålder, kön, funktionsnedsättning, ras, etnicitet, ursprung, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning, blir inkluderade i det sociala, ekonomiska och politiska livet.

10.3 - Säkerställa lika möjligheter och minska förekomsten av ojämlika utfall, bland annat genom att avskaffa diskriminerande lagstiftning, politik och praxis och främja lagstiftning, politik och åtgärder av lämpligt slag i detta hänseende.

10.3 - Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.
16.b - Verka för och genomdriva icke-diskriminerande lagstiftning och politik för en hållbar utveckling.
16.b - Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.
3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.c - Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.
5.c - Anta och stärka välgrundad politik och genomförbar lagstiftning för att främja jämställdhet och öka alla kvinnors och flickors egenmakt på alla nivåer
8.8 - Protect labour rights and promote safe and secure working environments for all workers, including migrant workers, in particular women migrants, and those in precarious employment.

8.8 - Skydda arbetstagarnas rättigheter och främja en trygg och säker arbetsmiljö för alla arbetstagare, inklusive arbetskraftsinvandrare, i synnerhet kvinnliga migranter, och människor i otrygga anställningar.

description.narrative: No results have been reported yet since implementation recently started (1st January 2020).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
